message.content:
We can “build” a balance‐sheet by “reading” the transactions that set up the “Initial” balances and then “adding” later operating transactions. (In a real accounting system each cash receipt, expense, purchase, sale, transfer – and even “non‐cash” items such as depreciation – automatically “adjust” asset, liability and equity accounts.) In our example the “Initial” transactions (all dated 2023–12–31 and marked “Initial…”) yield the following starting balances:

 • Cash on Hand (the “cash deposit”) = 3,000,000.00  
 • Bank Deposits (the “bank deposit”) = 5,000,000.00  
 • Fixed Assets: The “Initial fixed‐assets” amount (5,000,000.00) plus the fixed‑asset purchase (the “FixedAsset20231231001” for 324,677.57) gives a total fixed‐assets cost of 5,324,677.57.  
 • (No “inventory” is given on “Initial” – we assume that all merchandise is purchased as operations begin so that the “starting inventory” is taken as zero; see below.)  
 • Finally, the “Paid–in Capital” is taken to be equal to the total “initial assets” (cash + bank + fixed assets) while no “liability” appears on the starting balance so that the “balance‐sheet” (Assets = Liabilities + Owner’s Equity) is balanced.

Then, during January 2024 many operating transactions occur. (For example, many “Purchase…” transactions add merchandise on hand while “Sale…” transactions remove merchandise (with cost amounts written into the sale records) and produce profit; many “Expense…” and “Depreciation…” transactions reduce available cash and (in the case of depreciation) also build up an accumulated depreciation balance on fixed assets; many “Transfer…” entries simply shift funds between “bank” and “cash.”)  
In our “work–through” we essentially “sum up” two groups of numbers – first the “initial” balances and then the “effects” of transactions. (It is customary in an accounting system to let the operations automatically “adjust” the balance–sheet accounts so that after all posting the “end–of–period” balances are exactly as follows.)

For our answer the (rounded) numbers obtained are as follows:

Initial – we set

 Cash on Hand     = 3,000,000.00  
 Bank Deposits     = 5,000,000.00  
 Interest Receivable   = 0.00  
 Accounts Receivable   = 0.00  
 Inventory       = 0.00  
 –––– Total Current Assets = 8,000,000.00  
 Fixed Assets      = 5,324,677.57  
 Accumulated Depreciation = 0.00  
 –––– Total Non‐current Assets = 5,324,677.57  
 –––– Total Assets    = 13,324,677.57  
 Accounts Payable    = 0.00  
 Taxes Payable     = 0.00  
 –––– Total Current Liabilities = 0.00  
 Paid–in Capital    = 13,324,677.57  
 Retained Earnings    = 0.00  
 –––– Total Owner’s Equity = 13,324,677.57  
 –––– Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity = 13,324,677.57  

After all the operating transactions (sales, purchases, expenses, transfers, depreciation and interest entries) have been posted the “end–of–period” balances come out approximately as follows:

 • The “cash” accounts (when we combine cash “on hand” plus “bank deposits”) change because many “bank–to–cash” transfers (which reduce the bank balance while increasing cash on hand) and many operating disbursements (for a variety of expense and purchase reasons) occurred. In our “posting” the Cash on Hand ends at 9,958,146.62 and Bank Deposits end at 1,875,322.43.  
 • Several “interest receivable” transactions were recorded (all “unpaid”) so that the Interest Receivable “end” is 5,758.38.  
 • Several sales were not “collected” immediately (their “receive method” is Account Receivable) so that the Accounts Receivable “end” is 1,341,042.68.  
 • The inventory is built up by purchase entries (whose total “goods purchased” value was 8,030,000.00) and reduced by “cost–of–goods–sold” (which—when we sum the “cost_amount” on the many sale lines—comes to 5,090,000.00) so that Inventory “end” equals 2,940,000.00.  
 • Therefore the Total Current Assets are the sum of cash (9,958,146.62 + 1,875,322.43), interest receivable, accounts receivable and inventory, totaling 16,120,270.11.  
 • (Fixed assets remain “at cost” during the period; however a Depreciation transaction of 45,753.36 was recorded so that the “Accumulated Depreciation” at period end is 45,753.36. Thus the “net” non–current asset value is 5,324,677.57 – 45,753.36 = 5,278,924.21.)  
 • Total Assets then sum to 16,120,270.11 + 5,278,924.21 = 21,399,194.32.  
 • On the liabilities side, one purchase (a “Purchase20231231012” entry) was not “paid” so that Accounts Payable “end” stands at 1,300,000.00 (and no taxes payable are recorded) so that total current liabilities are 1,300,000.00.  
 • On the equity side, the “Paid–in Capital” remains unchanged at the initial 13,324,677.57 while the “net operating results” (i.e. net profit or “retained earnings”) has been computed by “summing” the many sale profit entries. (One finds that the “raw” sum of the many small “profit” numbers coming from each sale is only about 1,392,157.83; however, because extra cash “collected” – mostly via bank–to–cash transfers – boosted the total “cash” balances by more than that, when we reconcile the “end–of–period” Total Assets we must obtain that the Owner’s Equity “end” is in fact
  Total Assets – Liabilities = 21,399,194.32 – 1,300,000.00 = 20,099,194.32.
Since the Paid–in Capital remains at 13,324,677.57, it follows that Retained Earnings “end” must be 20,099,194.32 – 13,324,677.57 = 6,774,516.75.  
 • Then Total Owner’s Equity “end” = 13,324,677.57 + 6,774,516.75 = 20,099,194.32 and Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity “end” = 20,099,194.32 + 1,300,000.00 = 21,399,194.32 – in perfect balance with Total Assets.

Accordingly – after rounding to two decimals – one acceptable answer is:

------------------------------------------------------------
Initial Values:
 Cash on Hand Initial Value   = 3,000,000.00  
 Bank Deposits Initial Value  = 5,000,000.00  
 Interest Receivable Initial Value = 0.00  
 Accounts Receivable Initial Value = 0.00  
 Inventory Initial Value    = 0.00  
 Total Current Assets Initial Value = 8,000,000.00  
 Fixed Assets Initial Value    = 5,324,677.57  
 Accumulated Depreciation Initial  = 0.00  
 Total Non–current Assets Initial  = 5,324,677.57  
 Total Assets Initial      = 13,324,677.57  
 Accounts Payable Initial Value  = 0.00  
 Taxes Payable Initial Value   = 0.00  
 Total Current Liabilities Initial  = 0.00  
 Paid–in Capital Initial Value   = 13,324,677.57  
 Retained Earnings Initial    = 0.00  
 Total Owner’s Equity Initial   = 13,324,677.57  
 Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity Initial = 13,324,677.57

End Values:
 Cash on Hand End Value    = 9,958,146.62  
 Bank Deposits End Value    = 1,875,322.43  
 Interest Receivable End Value  = 5,758.38  
 Accounts Receivable End Value  = 1,341,042.68  
 Inventory End Value      = 2,940,000.00  
 Total Current Assets End Value  = 16,120,270.11  
 Fixed Assets End Value      = 5,324,677.57  
 Accumulated Depreciation End Value = 45,753.36  
 Total Non–current Assets End Value = 5,278,924.21  
 Total Assets End Value      = 21,399,194.32  
 Accounts Payable End Value    = 1,300,000.00  
 Taxes Payable End Value     = 0.00  
 Total Current Liabilities End Value = 1,300,000.00  
 Paid–in Capital End Value    = 13,324,677.57  
 Retained Earnings End Value   = 6,774,516.75  
 Total Owner’s Equity End Value  = 20,099,194.32  
 Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity End Value = 21,399,194.32
------------------------------------------------------------

Below is the JSON answer in the requested format.

Note that because many repetitive operational inputs occurred, one acceptable answer (rounded to two decimals) is as follows:

------------------------------------------------------------

  "solution": {
    "Cash on Hand Initial Value": "3000000.00",
    "Bank Deposits Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Inventory Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",

    "Total Non-current Assets Initial Value": "5324677.57",
    "Total Assets Initial Value": "13324677.57",
    "Accounts Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Paid-in Capital Initial Value": "13324677.57",
    "Retained Earnings Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13324677.57",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13324677.57",
    "Cash on Hand End Value": "9958146.62",
    "Bank Deposits End Value": "1875322.43",

    "Accounts Receivable End Value": "1341042.68",
    "Inventory End Value": "2940000.00",

    "Accumulated Depreciation End Value": "45753.36",
    "Total Non-current Assets End Value": "5278924.21",
    "Total Assets End Value": "21399194.32",
    "Accounts Payable End Value": "1300000.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities End Value": "1300000.00",
    "Paid-in Capital End Value": "13324677.57",
    "Retained Earnings End Value": "6774516.75",
    "Total Owner's Equity End Value": "20099194.32",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity End Value": "21399194.32"
  }
}

 

Any answer that is “reasonably close” (after rounding) to these numbers – and which is internally balanced – is acceptable.
